item.title: Critical Linking: March 29th, 2013
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.description:
I find myself thinking, with every post I make on Facebook or Twitter or Tumblr or the internet at large, “Oh, here’s further evidence for the future religious dictator-oppressors to use against me! item.title: 5 Books to Watch for in April
item.dc:creator: Emily Gatlin
item.description:
April is one of the kindest months for your soul. The weather starts to perk up, you get a little more comfortable wearing flip flops, and the hammock feels so nice. There are some really great new releases headed your way, all across the spectrum. The Interestings by Meg Wolitzer (Riverhead): This book is AMAZE. [...]

item.title: Name Those Authors!: March 28, 2013
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Joines Schinsky
item.description:
This round of Name Those Authors! is sponsored by Angelopolis by Danielle Trussoni. A New York Times bestseller and global sensation, Angelology unfurled a brilliant tapestry of myth and biblical lore on our present-day world and plunged two star-crossed heroes into an ancient battle against mankind’s greatest enemy: the fatally attractive angel-human hybrids known as the Nephilim. With Angelopolis, the conflict deepens [...]

item.title: When You Realize You Can’t Read All The Things

It’s happened again. You’ve logged on to Twitter, Tumblr, Facebook, just minding your own business, when suddenly someone has recommended a book you haven’t read, its TITLE IN ALL CAPS practically demanding you go put it on your “to read” list right now. item.title: Time Reading Is Time Well Spent
item.dc:creator: Greg Zimmerman
item.description:
I love reading, and therefore, I spend a disproportionate amount of my free time doing it. I am reader — it’s my “hobby,” it’s what I do. item.title: Would You Join a Private Library?
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.description:
I don’t know what it is exactly, but there something to getting out of the house for a while to read, work, or write. item.title: Critical Linking: March 28th, 2013
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.description:
Halpern’s definition of literary fiction seems like a winning one too: it stands out for its “allegiance to language”. Some people seem really hung up on trying to define literary fiction. This attempt seems as good as any, but it makes you realize how little “there” there is to the idea of literary fiction. [...]

item.title: Judging Other People’s Books
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Bastos
item.description:
I have a close friend, whom I adore, except we can’t talk about books: we never agree. Not that agreement is necessary, but disagreement about books among friends has a sumo quality to it. She thinks Orson Scott Card’s Ender’s Game is seminal. I hate it. I prefer the Alvin Maker series, which she sees [...]

item.title: Bibliotheca Alexandrina: The Great Library of Alexandria Reborn?
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.description:
Many have heard of The Library of Alexandria–the greatest center of learning and manuscripts in the ancient world.
